hawaiian_text: He keiki ‘u‘uku loa ‘o **a)** Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a he  keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ‘ōpiopio, ‘a‘ohe ona lua  ma kēia mau mokupuni mai Hawai‘i ā Ni‘ihau, i ka  ‘u‘uku a me ke koa loa. **b1)** ‘O Kauluakaha‘i, kona   makua kāne, **c)** no Kahikipapaialewa, he ‘āina i  Kahikinu‘u. **b2)** ‘O Pōka‘ī ka makuahine. **c)** He ali‘i  nui kona makua kāne no Kahikipapaialewa, a **b1)** he ‘ao‘ao akua kekahi ona.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_translation: Nāmakaokapāo‘o was a very small child, but he was a very strong child in his youth, and there was no one on these islands from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau who could match his small size and great strength. His father was Kauluakaha‘i, from Kahikipapaialewa, a land in Kahikinu‘u. His mother was Pōka‘ī. His father was a great chief of Kahikipapaialewa, and he was also of the godly line.
llama4-maverick-fireworks_commentary:
The passage introduces Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a figure of significance in Hawaiian cultural narratives, highlighting his extraordinary strength despite his small size. The text begins by establishing Nāmakaokapāo‘o's unique physical attributes and prowess, emphasizing that he was unmatched in strength among the islands from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau. This geographical reference encompasses the main Hawaiian Islands, underscoring Nāmakaokapāo‘o's exceptional status.

The mention of his parents, Kauluakaha‘i and Pōka‘ī, provides genealogical context, which is crucial in Hawaiian culture for understanding an individual's social status, spiritual connections, and ancestral lineage. The father's origin, Kahikipapaialewa in Kahikinu‘u, is significant as it ties Nāmakaokapāo‘o to a specific geographical and possibly spiritual or ancestral location. Kahikinu‘u is associated with the broader region of Kahiki, a term used in Hawaiian traditions to refer to places outside of Hawai‘i, often linked to ancestral homelands or spiritual realms.

The description of Kauluakaha‘i as a "he ali‘i nui" or great chief, indicates that Nāmakaokapāo‘o comes from a line of high-ranking chiefs, suggesting a connection to the ruling or noble class. The term "ali‘i" refers to the chiefly or aristocratic class in ancient Hawaiian society, who held significant power, wealth, and spiritual authority.

The phrase "he ‘ao‘ao akua kekahi ona" or "he was also of the godly line," is particularly noteworthy. It suggests that Kauluakaha‘i, and by extension Nāmakaokapāo‘o, have a divine or semi-divine ancestry. In Hawaiian culture, the concept of being "of the godly line" connects individuals to the akua (gods) and implies a sacred or spiritual dimension to their lineage and possibly their roles or destinies. This divine connection is a common feature in the genealogies of high-ranking chiefs and is used to legitimize their rule and authority.

Linguistically, the passage employs classical Hawaiian narrative style, characterized by the use of metaphorical language and genealogical references to establish the subject's identity and significance. The text assumes a level of cultural knowledge about Hawaiian genealogy, geography, and the importance of chiefly lineage, reflecting the oral traditions and historical narratives that were central to Hawaiian culture.

Historically, this passage reflects the importance of genealogy and ancestral connections in understanding an individual's place within Hawaiian society. It also highlights the cultural values placed on strength, lineage, and spiritual or divine connections, which were integral to the social and political structures of ancient Hawai‘i.

His father was Kauluakaha‘i, from Kahikipapaialewa, a land in Kahikinu‘u. His mother was Pōka‘ī. His father was a great chief of Kahikipapaialewa, and he was also of the godly line.</translation>

The term "ali‘i" refers to the chiefly or aristocratic class in ancient Hawaiian society, who held significant power, wealth, and spiritual authority.

It suggests that Kauluakaha‘i, and by extension Nāmakaokapāo‘o, have a divine or semi-divine ancestry. This divine connection is a common feature in the genealogies of high-ranking chiefs and is used to legitimize their rule and authority.

reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo‘o was a little boy and incredibly  strong when he was very young. There was no one  like him from Hawai‘i all the way to Ni‘ihau in his  small stature and bravery. Kauluakaha‘i was his  father from Kahikipapaialewa, a place in  Kahikinu‘u. Pōka‘ī was his mother. His father was a  high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, who was also part  god.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 1:**• It is very common in Hawaiian storytelling to open by  disclosing:  **a)** the name of the main protagonist/s, and   sometimes a description of their (aproximate) age  and/or physique/physical attributes;  **b)** the name of the parent/s, grandparent/s,  caregiver/s of the main protagonist/s, and sometimes  a description;  **c)** the name of the place the main protagonist/s grew  up or are living in at the time the story takes place;  • The main protagonists described in the first  paragraph are:  1\) Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o (m) (the eyes of the pāo‘o  fish): an incredibly strong, young boy, with no  comparison from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau for his small  stature and strength; 2\) Ka-ulu-a-kaha‘i (m) (the inspiration of Kaha‘i (Footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1977:385): Kaha‘i: “A hero who traveled to ‘Upolu, Samoa, and brought back breadfruit to Haki-pu‘u, Oahu (according to some versions) or to Pu‘u-loa, Kohala,  Hawaii (HM 97). He was born at ‘Ī-ao, Maui. He went to Kahiki to find his father, Hema, who had lost his eyes (HM 248). See Nā-maka-o-Kaha‘i.), Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s father; a high chief of Kahiki-papa ia-lewa (Kahiki stratum in the sky, likely a foreign  country), a place in Kahiki-nu‘u (Kahiki at the summit,  a foreign country); he is a demigod;  3\) Pō-ka-‘ī (f) (perhaps ʻnight falls upon the high  chief’): Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s mother; no further  description;
